head.title: Arts, Briefly; Italy to Return a Venus

hedline.hl1: Arts, Briefly; Italy to Return a Venus

body.head.byline: By ELISABETTA POVOLEDO; Compiled by Lawrence Van Gelder

block.p: A Rome court ruled this week that Italy must return a second-century statue of Venus to Libya. In a statement, the Italian culture ministry said it was satisfied with the decision, which it described as an ''important legal precedent'' and ''coherent'' with Italy's own efforts to recover illegally exported artifacts from foreign museums and collectors. The legal battle over the statue, above, began nearly five years ago when then Prime Minister Silvio Berlusconi ceded to Libyan demands to return the statue, which had been found by an Italian archaeological expedition in 1913 at Cyrene, an ancient Greek colony, later Romanized, that is now a Unesco World Heritage site. Italia Nostra, a conservation group, had challenged the restitution, arguing that the headless statue was part of Italy's cultural heritage, but on Monday an administrative court dismissed the challenge.
